title: What is an IPO?
description: An IPO (Initial Public Offering) is when a private company offers shares to the public for the first time, allowing investors to buy ownership.
details: An IPO marks the transition of a private company to a public one. It allows investors to buy shares and provides capital to the company for expansion.

title: How Does an IPO Work?
description: Learn about the IPO process — from selecting underwriters to stock market listing.
details: The IPO process involves hiring investment banks, filing documents with SEBI, marketing the issue, setting a price band, and finally listing the shares.

title: How to Invest in an IPO?
description: Understand how retail investors can apply for IPOs through brokers and banks.
details: Investors can apply using ASBA (Applications Supported by Blocked Amount) via their bank or broker account. After allotment, shares appear in the Demat account.

title: Why Companies Go Public?
description: Discover the key reasons why companies launch IPOs.
details: Companies go public to raise capital, gain visibility, allow early investors to exit, and attract talent with stock-based compensation.

title: Risks of Investing in IPOs
description: Learn the potential risks before investing in IPOs.
details: IPOs can be risky due to limited historical data, volatile pricing, and market uncertainty. Always read the prospectus before investing.

title: IPO Share Allotment Process
description: How are IPO shares distributed among investors?
details: Shares are allocated based on demand, category (retail/institutional), and SEBI rules. Oversubscription may lead to partial allotment or lottery-based distribution.

title: IPO vs Direct Listing
description: Understand the key difference between traditional IPOs and direct listings.
details: In an IPO, new shares are issued to raise capital, while in a direct listing, existing shares are sold without raising new funds. Direct listings avoid underwriting fees and are preferred by already well-known companies.

title: Lock-in Period Explained
description: Learn why promoters and early investors can’t sell shares immediately after an IPO.
details: A lock-in period is a time frame (typically 6 months) after an IPO during which company insiders and early investors cannot sell their shares. This ensures market stability post-listing.
